Let me synthesize what I know:

1. **Current state:** IC (Individual Contributor) in healthcare/pharma, product/strategy background, has deployed at least one AI/ML solution professionally
2. **Interests:** Agentic AI (process automation) and Decision support/Analytics
3. **Target role:** Unsure ‚Äî needs help thinking through this
4. **Biggest gap:** Enterprise stakeholder buy-in
5. **AI team status:** Just getting built ‚Äî they're in the early stages of forming an AI capability

This is a rich career planning task. Let me now create ISC criteria and work through the full algorithm to:


- Help them think through the right target role
- Identify skills to develop
- Update their talent profile
- Map career progression

Given their product/strategy background, desire to prototype and hand off, and the nascent AI team, I'm thinking they're best positioned as an Innovation Lead or AI Strategist‚Äîthe person who builds the initial proof of concept and then transitions it to the team. They're the "zero to one" person, not scaling it afterward.

For skills, they need enough technical depth to build credible prototypes‚ÄîPython, LLM APIs, and retrieval-augmented generation fundamentals‚Äîbut the real leverage is in their ability to navigate enterprise stakeholder dynamics and translate business problems into AI solutions.

Now I'm mapping out the full skill set they should develop: technical foundations in agentic frameworks and prompt engineering, strategic capabilities around business case development and ROI modeling, healthcare-specific knowledge of regulations and clinical workflows, and the soft skills to communicate with executives and lead cross-functional teams. Their career path in enterprise healthcare would move from individual contributor to senior IC or innovation lead, then into management of AI innovation, eventually reaching director or VP level roles in AI strategy.

‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ üìã PLAN ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ 3/7

**Approach:** Use FirstPrinciples to decompose what the "enterprise AI prototyper" archetype really needs, then Council to debate the target role, then synthesize into profile updates and career map.

‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ üî® BUILD + ‚ö° EXECUTE ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ 4-5/7

### ISC #1: Target Role ‚Äî **AI Innovation Lead**

content.content: Updated task #1 status

content.text:
Here's the FirstPrinciples decomposition of what you described:

**What you actually want to do:**
1. Identify AI opportunities in the enterprise
2. Build POC/prototypes to prove feasibility
3. Make the business case for investment
4. Hand off to a delivery team if approved
5. Move to the next opportunity

**That maps to exactly one archetype: Innovation Lead / AI Strategist.** Here's why the other options don't fit:

| Role | Why NOT for you |
|------|----------------|
| AI Product Manager | Owns the product long-term ‚Äî you want to hand off |
| AI Solutions Architect | Deep technical design focus ‚Äî your strength is product/strategy |
| Technical Program Manager | Coordination role ‚Äî you want to ideate and build, not manage timelines |

**Why Innovation Lead fits:**
- Your product/strategy background IS the core competency ‚Äî you understand "what to build and why"
- Code-assisted prototyping means you can build credible demos without being a full engineer
- The AI team is just getting built ‚Äî you'd be shaping what gets built, not joining a machine
- Healthcare/pharma needs people who bridge clinical domain + AI possibility. That's product thinking.

**Recommended title to position for:** **AI Innovation Lead** or **AI Solutions Lead** (depending on your enterprise's naming conventions)

content.content: Updated task #1 status

### ISC #2: Skills Gap Analysis

content.content: Updated task #2 status

content.text:
**Skills you HAVE (product/strategy + 1 deployed AI project):**
- Product strategy and roadmapping
- Healthcare/pharma domain knowledge
- Stakeholder communication
- Basic AI/ML project delivery experience
- Business case development

**Skills to DEVELOP (prioritized for the Innovation Lead role):**

#### Tier 1 ‚Äî Critical (next 3 months)
| Skill | Why Critical | How to Develop |
|-------|-------------|----------------|
| **Prompt engineering & LLM APIs** | Foundation of every prototype you'll build | Build 3 POCs using OpenAI/Claude APIs with different patterns |
| **Agentic AI frameworks** | Your #1 project interest ‚Äî must demo competently | LangGraph or CrewAI tutorial ‚Üí build a healthcare workflow agent |
| **AI business case & ROI modeling** | Your biggest gap is stakeholder buy-in ‚Äî this is the weapon | Study enterprise AI ROI frameworks, build templates for your org |
| **Enterprise AI governance basics** | Healthcare = regulated. You must speak this language. | NIST AI RMF + your org's data governance policies |

#### Tier 2 ‚Äî Important (months 3-9)
| Skill | Why Important | How to Develop |
|-------|--------------|----------------|
| **RAG architecture patterns** | Decision support systems need retrieval ‚Äî your #2 interest | Build a RAG pipeline over internal docs using a vector DB |
| **Cloud AI services (Azure/AWS/GCP)** | Enterprise deploys on cloud ‚Äî must know what's available | Certification path (Azure AI Fundamentals ‚Üí Azure AI Engineer Associate) |
| **Executive storytelling for AI** | Translates POCs into funded projects | Practice: 5-minute pitch deck for each prototype |
| **Healthcare data standards (FHIR/HL7)** | Data is the bottleneck in healthcare AI ‚Äî know the plumbing | FHIR spec overview + how it intersects with AI pipelines |

#### Tier 3 ‚Äî Differentiator (months 9-18)
| Skill | Why Differentiating | How to Develop |
|-------|-------------------|----------------|
| **AI evaluation & benchmarking** | Proves your prototypes work, not just demo well | Learn eval frameworks (RAGAS for RAG, custom metrics for agents) |
| **Vendor evaluation** | Enterprise will ask "build vs. buy?" ‚Äî you should lead that conversation | Build a scoring rubric, evaluate 3 vendors per project type |
| **Change management for AI adoption** | Getting people to USE AI, not just approve it | Prosci or similar framework, adapted for AI tooling rollout |

### ISC #5: Stakeholder Buy-in Strategy (your biggest gap)

content.content: Updated task #5 status

content.text:
Since this is your self-identified biggest gap, here's a concrete playbook:

**The "Proof Before Permission" Strategy:**

1. **Start with pain, not technology.** Find a process that's visibly broken/slow/expensive. Build the POC against THAT, not "let's use AI."
2. **Demo > Deck.** A working 5-minute demo beats a 30-slide strategy deck. Your code-assisted prototyping ability is the weapon here.
3. **Find your executive sponsor.** One VP who gets it is worth more than org-wide awareness. Target the leader whose team has the pain from step 1.
4. **Speak in their language.** Healthcare execs care about: time-to-decision, error reduction, compliance risk, FTE hours saved. NOT: "LLM," "agentic," "RAG."
5. **Build a "wins log."** Every small win (even a demo that impressed someone) goes in a running document. This becomes your portfolio AND your budget justification.
6. **Create FOMO.** Share what competitors are doing with AI in healthcare. "Pfizer/UnitedHealth/etc. just deployed X" is a powerful motivator.

content.content: Updated task #5 status

content.thinking:
This is a profound insight from the user. They're thinking ahead to a world where AI prototyping is commoditized. They're asking: "If everyone can build AI prototypes, what's my moat?"

This changes the entire framing. Let me think about this through FirstPrinciples:

**The question behind the question:** When the technical barrier to building AI solutions drops to near-zero (and it's happening fast), what becomes the scarce, valuable skill?

The answer isn't the technology. It's:
1. **Problem selection** ‚Äî knowing WHAT to build (domain expertise + strategic judgment)
2. **Organizational orchestration** ‚Äî getting enterprises to actually adopt and change


3. **Systems thinking** ‚Äî understanding how AI fits into complex business ecosystems
4. **Judgment under uncertainty** ‚Äî deciding between 100 possible AI applications, which 3 will actually create value
5. **Trust and influence** ‚Äî the human network that decides where resources go

So the real career move isn't becoming better at building AI‚Äîit's becoming the person who knows which AI problems matter, how to navigate organizational adoption, and can command the resources and trust to make it happen. That trajectory points toward Chief AI Officer or Chief Innovation Officer roles where the leverage comes from strategic vision and organizational influence, not technical execution.

The capabilities that actually matter at that level are strategic judgment about which problems are worth solving, organizational design to restructure around AI capabilities, ethics and governance as these systems become more powerful, and the ability to recognize patterns across industries‚Äîseeing what worked in finance and applying it to pharma. It's also about vendor strategy at scale and the executive presence to shape board-level decisions about how the company transforms.

This is the right question to ask. Let me rethink the entire plan around this insight.

‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ üîÑ REVISED BUILD ‚îÅ‚îÅ‚îÅ

### The Deeper Question: When AI Building Is Commoditized, What's Scarce?

You're right that frameworks and prototyping will get easier. They already are. So let's decompose what remains valuable using FirstPrinciples:

**What AI commoditizes:** Building, coding, prototyping, basic implementation
**What AI CANNOT commoditize:**

| Scarce Skill | Why It Stays Scarce | Enterprise Value |
|---|---|---|
| **Problem selection judgment** | Knowing which of 200 possible AI projects will actually create value requires deep domain expertise + strategic sense. AI can build anything ‚Äî knowing WHAT to build is the moat. | This is how budgets get allocated |
| **Organizational transformation** | Getting 10,000 people to actually change how they work is a human orchestration problem, not a technology problem | This is how AI projects survive past the demo |
| **Governance & risk judgment** | Healthcare + AI = high stakes. Someone has to decide what's safe, ethical, and compliant. That requires domain depth + values + political skill | This is how enterprises avoid catastrophic AI failures |
| **Cross-domain pattern recognition** | Seeing that what worked for claims processing also applies to clinical trial recruitment ‚Äî that requires breadth | This is how you 10x the innovation pipeline |
| **Trust-based influence** | The C-suite funds people they trust, not technology they understand | This is how ideas become investments |

### Revised Career Ladder ‚Äî Thinking Beyond VP

```
NOW                12-18 MO              3-5 YR                 5-8 YR                  8-12 YR
‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
IC                 AI Innovation Lead    Sr. AI Strategy Lead    VP / Head of AI         Chief AI Officer
(Product/Strategy)                                               Innovation              or Chief Innovation
                                                                                         Officer

Your moat:         Your moat:            Your moat:              Your moat:              Your moat:
Domain knowledge   "I know WHAT to       "I've built a           "I redesign how the     "I set the AI
+ AI curiosity     build and can          repeatable system       enterprise operates     strategy for the
                   prove it works"        for finding +           with AI ‚Äî not just      entire company
                                          validating AI           what tools we use,      and sit at the
                                          opportunities"          but how we WORK"        table with the
                                                                                          board"

Commoditized at    Commoditized at       Commoditized at         Commoditized at         NOT commoditized:
this level:        this level:           this level:             this level:             Strategic judgment
Nothing yet        Prototyping           POC building            Even strategy           + org transformation
                   (others can too)      (AI tools do this)      consulting gets AI      + trust = human
                                                                  augmented               capital forever
```

### The Skills That Matter in a Post-Commoditization World

I'm restructuring the skill tiers around **what stays scarce**:

#### Tier 1 ‚Äî Build NOW (these compound over time)
| Skill | Why It's Durable | How to Start |
|---|---|---|
| **Healthcare AI governance & ethics** | Regulatory judgment can't be automated. FDA, HIPAA, clinical safety ‚Äî you need to be the person in the room who knows what's allowed | Study NIST AI RMF + FDA AI/ML action plan. Become your org's go-to on "can we do this?" |
| **Business case architecture** | Not just ROI spreadsheets ‚Äî framing AI opportunities as strategic bets with risk/reward | Build a reusable framework: problem ‚Üí data feasibility ‚Üí effort ‚Üí value ‚Üí risk |
| **Executive communication & influence** | The skill that converts prototypes into funded programs. Human trust doesn't commoditize. | Practice: 3-minute pitch for every POC. Get feedback from directors/VPs. |
| **Agentic AI + LLM fluency** | You still need enough technical depth to evaluate what's possible and guide teams | Build 3-5 prototypes. Not to prove you can code ‚Äî to build intuition for what's feasible. |

#### Tier 2 ‚Äî Build in 3-9 months (strategic differentiation)
| Skill | Why It's Durable | How to Start |
|---|---|---|
| **Organizational change management** | When everyone can prototype, the bottleneck is adoption. You need to move the humans. | Prosci certification or equivalent. Apply it to your first AI rollout. |
| **Cross-domain pattern recognition** | Read broadly: what's working in fintech, retail, defense AI? Translate patterns to pharma. | Set up a weekly AI industry scan. Build a "patterns library" of cross-industry insights. |
| **Data strategy & data governance** | Models commoditize. DATA doesn't. The person who understands the enterprise data landscape wins. | Map your org's data assets. Know where the gold is and what's locked behind governance. |
| **Vendor strategy & build/buy/partner** | Enterprises will buy more AI than they build. Knowing when to buy vs. build = massive leverage. | Evaluate 3 vendors per quarter. Build a scoring framework. |

#### Tier 3 ‚Äî Build in 9-18 months (executive trajectory)
| Skill | Why It's Durable |
|---|---|
| **Board-level AI communication** | Translate AI implications into business risk and opportunity for non-technical leaders |
| **AI portfolio management** | Managing a portfolio of AI bets like a VC ‚Äî fund/kill/pivot based on evidence |
| **Enterprise architecture thinking** | Not just individual AI solutions ‚Äî how AI reshapes the entire operating model |
| **Industry thought leadership** | Publishing, speaking, building external reputation. This compounds and creates gravity. |

### The Key Insight for Your Profile

Your internal positioning shouldn't be **"I build AI prototypes."** It should be:

> **"I identify the highest-value AI opportunities in our enterprise, prove they work, and orchestrate the organization to adopt them."**

That's not a statement about technology. It's a statement about judgment, influence, and transformation. It stays true whether prototyping takes 2 weeks or 2 hours.

# Strategies

## S1: Constraint-First Evaluation
Before evaluating scientific merit or technical feasibility, map the constraint landscape. A brilliant idea with an immovable regulatory constraint is worse than a modest idea with a clear path.

## S2: Cross-Functional Questions Before Cross-Functional Meetings
Written, structured questions get better answers than live meetings. People think more carefully when they write. Send questions ‚Üí collect responses ‚Üí synthesize ‚Üí then meet only to resolve conflicts.

## S3: Small Pilots, Fast Kills
Get to a 4-week pilot or kill the project. The cost of a failed pilot is one month. The cost of a stalled committee proposal is six months of everyone's time.

## S4: Make the Invisible Visible
Use structured artifacts (constraint tables, ISC tracking, evaluation scorecards) so that implicit knowledge becomes explicit and debatable.

## S5: 3-Month AI Displacement Test
Before investing evaluation effort in any project, apply the displacement test: "Will AI's exponential growth in 3 months make this work MORE valuable or OBSOLETE?" Projects that ride the AI curve (amplifiers) pass. Projects that compete with AI's trajectory (bespoke solutions AI will do better) fail. Apply this gate BEFORE constraint mapping (S1) to avoid sunk evaluation cost on strategically misaligned projects.

- How AI capability curves affect R&D investment decisions
- Cross-functional collaboration patterns that actually work in pharma
- Structured evaluation frameworks that surface invisible constraints early
- The gap between "interesting AI research" and "deployed AI tools that scientists use"

- [ ] Deepen understanding of clinical trial endpoints and statistical design
- [ ] Learn enough about transformer architectures to evaluate feasibility claims
- [ ] Study successful AI deployments in pharma (case studies, failure modes)
- [x] Build a repeatable constraint-first evaluation framework (using PAI)

- **Seeking mentorship in:** Deep ML technical feasibility assessment, regulatory pathway knowledge
- **Preferred format:** Written async (structured questions ‚Üí responses), supplemented with short syncs

# Interests

## Professional Interests
- How AI capability curves affect R&D investment decisions
- Cross-functional collaboration patterns that actually work in pharma
- Structured evaluation frameworks that surface invisible constraints early
- The gap between "interesting AI research" and "deployed AI tools that scientists use"
- **Enterprise AI adoption at scale** ‚Äî what makes organizations actually change how they work
- **Post-commoditization AI strategy** ‚Äî when anyone can prototype, what stays scarce? (judgment, orchestration, governance)
- **Agentic AI for process automation** ‚Äî AI agents that automate healthcare workflows, approvals, document processing
- **Decision support systems** ‚Äî AI-powered insights, forecasting, clinical and business decision aids

## Project Types I Want to Work On
| Project Type | Interest Level | Why |
|-------------|---------------|-----|
| Agentic AI / Process Automation | High | Biggest near-term enterprise impact; automates visible pain points |
| Decision Support / Analytics | High | Combines domain expertise with AI; high-value in clinical settings |
| RAG / Knowledge Systems | Medium | Enables decision support; practical for internal knowledge management |
| Customer/Patient-Facing AI | Low | Prefer internal enterprise adoption first |

## Learning Goals
- [ ] Build 3-5 code-assisted prototypes (LLM APIs + agentic frameworks) to develop intuition
- [ ] Complete AI business case architecture framework for enterprise pitches
- [ ] Study NIST AI RMF + FDA AI/ML guidance to become the "can we do this?" person

- [ ] Learn enough about transformer architectures to evaluate feasibility claims
- [ ] Study successful AI deployments in pharma (case studies, failure modes)

- [ ] Build a cross-industry AI patterns library (what works in fintech/retail ‚Üí pharma translation)
- [ ] Study organizational change management for AI adoption (Prosci or equivalent)

## Mentoring Preferences
- **Willing to mentor on:** Cross-functional AI project evaluation, stakeholder management, constraint surfacing, AI opportunity identification
- **Seeking mentorship in:** Deep ML technical feasibility assessment, regulatory pathway knowledge, executive-level AI communication, enterprise data strategy
- **Preferred format:** Written async (structured questions ‚Üí responses), supplemented with short syncs

## Career Transition Goal (2026-2027)
**Target Role:** AI Innovation Lead ‚Äî the person who identifies the highest-value AI opportunities, proves they work, and orchestrates the organization to adopt them.

input.old_string:
## S5: 3-Month AI Displacement Test
Before investing evaluation effort in any project, apply the displacement test: "Will AI's exponential growth in 3 months make this work MORE valuable or OBSOLETE?" Projects that ride the AI curve (amplifiers) pass. Projects that compete with AI's trajectory (bespoke solutions AI will do better) fail. Apply this gate BEFORE constraint mapping (S1) to avoid sunk evaluation cost on strategically misaligned projects.
input.new_string:
## S5: 3-Month AI Displacement Test
Before investing evaluation effort in any project, apply the displacement test: "Will AI's exponential growth in 3 months make this work MORE valuable or OBSOLETE?" Projects that ride the AI curve (amplifiers) pass. Projects that compete with AI's trajectory (bespoke solutions AI will do better) fail. Apply this gate BEFORE constraint mapping (S1) to avoid sunk evaluation cost on strategically misaligned projects.

## S6: Proof Before Permission
Don't ask for a budget to explore AI. Build a prototype against a visible pain point, demo it to the person who owns that pain, and let the demo create the demand. A working 5-minute demo beats a 30-slide strategy deck. Find one VP sponsor who gets it ‚Äî one champion is worth more than org-wide awareness.

## S7: Speak Outcomes, Not Technology
Healthcare execs care about: time-to-decision, error reduction, compliance risk, FTE hours saved. They don't care about: LLMs, RAG, agentic, embeddings. Every pitch, every demo, every email ‚Äî translate technology into the outcomes they're measured on.

## S8: Build for the Post-Commoditization World
When AI prototyping is commoditized (and it will be), three things stay scarce: (1) judgment about WHAT to build, (2) ability to orchestrate organizational change, (3) governance and risk judgment in regulated domains. Invest disproportionately in these skills. Technical depth serves as credibility fuel, not as the core value proposition.

## S9: Compound Credibility Through a Wins Log
Document every prototype, demo, stakeholder reaction, and outcome in a running log. Each small win compounds into a portfolio that justifies bigger bets. The wins log becomes your budget justification, your promotion case, and your proof of capability ‚Äî all in one artifact.

## S10: Create FOMO as a Strategic Tool
Track what competitors and peer enterprises are doing with AI. "Pfizer just deployed X" or "UnitedHealth reduced Y by 40% with AI" is a powerful motivator for enterprise leadership who otherwise delay decisions.

# Strategies

## S1: Constraint-First Evaluation
Before evaluating scientific merit or technical feasibility, map the constraint landscape. A brilliant idea with an immovable regulatory constraint is worse than a modest idea with a clear path.

## S2: Cross-Functional Questions Before Cross-Functional Meetings
Written, structured questions get better answers than live meetings. People think more carefully when they write. Send questions ‚Üí collect responses ‚Üí synthesize ‚Üí then meet only to resolve conflicts.

## S3: Small Pilots, Fast Kills
Get to a 4-week pilot or kill the project. The cost of a failed pilot is one month. The cost of a stalled committee proposal is six months of everyone's time.

## S4: Make the Invisible Visible
Use structured artifacts (constraint tables, ISC tracking, evaluation scorecards) so that implicit knowledge becomes explicit and debatable.

## S5: 3-Month AI Displacement Test
Before investing evaluation effort in any project, apply the displacement test: "Will AI's exponential growth in 3 months make this work MORE valuable or OBSOLETE?" Projects that ride the AI curve (amplifiers) pass. Projects that compete with AI's trajectory (bespoke solutions AI will do better) fail. Apply this gate BEFORE constraint mapping (S1) to avoid sunk evaluation cost on strategically misaligned projects.

input.old_string:
# Mission

I identify and champion AI-driven R&D projects that accelerate drug discovery at AstraZeneca. I bridge the gap between what's scientifically possible and what's organizationally achievable.

My value is not in doing the science or building the models ‚Äî it's in seeing across domains, spotting where AI can solve real workflow pain points, and building the cross-functional buy-in that gets projects from idea to pilot.

**Strategic Filter (2026-02-07):** I focus exclusively on projects that benefit from the exponential increase in AI capabilities. I deprioritize any project where the work will be obsolete within 3 months due to AI advancement. The test is binary: "Will AI's growth make this work MORE valuable (pursue) or OBSOLETE (deprioritize)?"
input.new_string:
# Mission

I identify the highest-value AI opportunities in our enterprise, prove they work through code-assisted prototypes, and orchestrate the organization to adopt them. I bridge the gap between what's scientifically possible and what's organizationally achievable.

My value is not in doing the science or building the models ‚Äî it's in **judgment** (knowing WHAT to build), **influence** (getting it funded and adopted), and **governance** (knowing what's safe and compliant in healthcare). These skills stay valuable as AI building becomes commoditized.

**Career Trajectory:** IC (Product/Strategy) ‚Üí AI Innovation Lead (12-18 mo) ‚Üí Sr. AI Strategy Lead (3-5 yr) ‚Üí Director/VP AI Strategy (5-8 yr) ‚Üí Chief AI/Innovation Officer (8-12 yr)

**Strategic Filter (2026-02-07):** I focus exclusively on projects that benefit from the exponential increase in AI capabilities. I deprioritize any project where the work will be obsolete within 3 months due to AI advancement. The test is binary: "Will AI's growth make this work MORE valuable (pursue) or OBSOLETE (deprioritize)?"

**Post-Commoditization Filter (2026-02-08):** When evaluating my own skill development, I ask: "Will this skill be more valuable or less valuable when anyone can prototype AI solutions?" I invest disproportionately in what stays scarce: problem selection judgment, organizational transformation, governance, and trust-based influence.
